content.text:
{
  "legal_audit": [
    {
      "law_cited": "Santiago v. Massachusetts Dep’t of Corr., 22 MDLR 290, 292 (2000)",
      "citation_context": "In order to establish a prima facie case of unlawful discrimination, Complainant must establish that (1) she was a member of a protected class; (2) she satisfactorily performed her job; (3) she experienced an adverse employment action; and (4) such adverse employment action occurred under circumstances giving rise to an inference of discrimination. See Santiago v. Massachusetts Dep’t of Corr., 22 MDLR 290, 292 (2000); Moridi v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 21 MDLR 39, 40 (1999); Wetzel v. Gen. Elec., 19 MDLR 53 (1997); Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harvard Coll., 432 Mass. 107, 116 (2000).",
      "associated_category": "Discrimination (Age, Race, National Origin, Color, Disability)",
      "legal_background": "This case is cited for the prima facie burden in disparate treatment claims: membership in a protected class, satisfactory job performance, adverse action, and circumstances suggesting discrimination. Once the prima facie case is made, the burden shifts to the employer to articulate a legitimate, non-discriminatory reason, and then back to the employee to show pretext. Used here to frame the threshold showing for the employee’s discrimination claims.",
      "relevance_score": "High"
    },
    {
      "law_cited": "Moridi v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 21 MDLR 39, 40 (1999)",
      "citation_context": "In order to establish a prima facie case of unlawful discrimination, Complainant must establish that (1) she was a member of a protected class; (2) she satisfactorily performed her job; (3) she experienced an adverse employment action; and (4) such adverse employment action occurred under circumstances giving rise to an inference of discrimination. See Santiago v. Massachusetts Dep’t of Corr., 22 MDLR 290, 292 (2000); Moridi v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 21 MDLR 39, 40 (1999); Wetzel v. Gen. Elec., 19 MDLR 53 (1997); Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harvard Coll., 432 Mass. 107, 116 (2000).",
      "associated_category": "Discrimination (Age, Race, National Origin, Color, Disability)",
      "legal_background": "Moridi is cited for the Massachusetts Commission Against Discrimination (MCAD) standard for establishing a prima facie case of discrimination in employment. It supports use of the McDonnell Douglas burden-shifting framework: prima facie showing, employer’s legitimate reason, and employee’s proof of pretext.",
      "relevance_score": "High"
    },
    {
      "law_cited": "Wetzel v. Gen. Elec., 19 MDLR 53 (1997)",
      "citation_context": "In order to establish a prima facie case of unlawful discrimination, Complainant must establish that (1) she was a member of a protected class; (2) she satisfactorily performed her job; (3) she experienced an adverse employment action; and (4) such adverse employment action occurred under circumstances giving rise to an inference of discrimination. See Santiago v. Massachusetts Dep’t of Corr., 22 MDLR 290, 292 (2000); Moridi v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 21 MDLR 39, 40 (1999); Wetzel v. Gen. Elec., 19 MDLR 53 (1997); Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harvard Coll., 432 Mass. 107, 116 (2000).",
      "associated_category": "Discrimination (Age, Race, National Origin, Color, Disability)",
      "legal_background": "Wetzel is another MCAD authority affirming the elements of a prima facie discrimination claim and the application of the burden-shifting analysis. It underscores that an employee must show satisfactory performance and circumstances permitting an inference of discriminatory motive.",
      "relevance_score": "High"
    },
    {
      "law_cited": "Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harvard Coll., 432 Mass. 107, 116 (2000)",
      "citation_context": "In order to establish a prima facie case of unlawful discrimination, Complainant must establish that (1) she was a member of a protected class; (2) she satisfactorily performed her job; (3) she experienced an adverse employment action; and (4) such adverse employment action occurred under circumstances giving rise to an inference of discrimination. See Santiago v. Massachusetts Dep’t of Corr., 22 MDLR 290, 292 (2000); Moridi v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 21 MDLR 39, 40 (1999); Wetzel v. Gen. Elec., 19 MDLR 53 (1997); Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harvard Coll., 432 Mass. 107, 116 (2000).",
      "associated_category": "Discrimination (Age, Race, National Origin, Color, Disability)",
      "legal_background": "Abramian is a leading Massachusetts case applying the McDonnell Douglas framework to employment discrimination under Chapter 151B. It recognizes the prima facie elements and the shift to the employer to provide a legitimate reason, followed by the employee’s burden to prove pretext. Also cited elsewhere in the document for pretext (pinpoint 118).",
      "relevance_score": "High"
    },
    {
      "law_cited": "Lipchitz v. Raytheon Co., 434 Mass. 493, 501 (2001)",
      "citation_context": "Even assuming that Complainant could establish a prima facie case of age discrimination (which she cannot), her claim fails because she cannot establish that the reasons for her Corrective Action Notices were untrue and a pretext for discrimination. See Lipchitz v. Raytheon Co., 434 Mass. 493, 501 (2001); Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harvard Coll., 432 Mass. 107, 118 (2000).",
      "associated_category": "Discrimination (pretext analysis)",
      "legal_background": "Lipchitz clarifies that, in Massachusetts, showing the employer’s stated reason is false can permit a factfinder to infer discriminatory animus, but the ultimate burden of persuasion remains with the employee. Employers prevail if they demonstrate a credible, non-discriminatory rationale and the employee cannot prove pretext.",
      "relevance_score": "High"
    },
    {
      "law_cited": "Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harvard Coll., 432 Mass. 107, 118 (2000)",
      "citation_context": "Even assuming that Complainant could establish a prima facie case of age discrimination (which she cannot), her claim fails because she cannot establish that the reasons for her Corrective Action Notices were untrue and a pretext for discrimination. See Lipchitz v. Raytheon Co., 434 Mass. 493, 501 (2001); Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harvard Coll., 432 Mass. 107, 118 (2000).",
      "associated_category": "Discrimination (pretext analysis)",
      "legal_background": "This pinpoint citation to Abramian addresses the pretext stage, reinforcing that the plaintiff must prove that the employer’s reason was not only false but that discrimination was the real reason. It supports the employer’s defense when contemporaneous, performance-based reasons are documented.",
      "relevance_score": "High"
    },
    {
      "law_cited": "Mole v. Univ. of Mass., 442 Mass. 582, 591-92 (2004)",
      "citation_context": "To establish a prima facie case of retaliation, Complainant must show (1) she engaged in a statutorily protected activity, of which Respondents were aware; (2) she suffered an adverse employment action; and (3) there is some causal relationship between the two events. See Mole v. Univ. of Mass., 442 Mass. 582, 591-92 (2004).",
      "associated_category": "Retaliation",
      "legal_background": "Mole sets out the Massachusetts prima facie framework for retaliation: protected activity, employer knowledge, adverse action, and causal connection. Temporal proximity alone is insufficient if the employer’s expectations and performance issues predate the protected activity.",
      "relevance_score": "High"
    },
    {
      "law_cited": "Ameen v. Amphenol Printed Circuits, Inc., 777 F.3d 63, 70 (1st Cir. 2015)",
      "citation_context": "Moreover, Complainant has not shown that Ms. Benoit was aware of Complainant’s EEOC filing. Ameen v. Amphenol Printed Circuits, Inc., 777 F.3d 63, 70 (1st Cir. 2015) ([Plaintiff] must show the retaliator knew about [her] protected activity – after all, one cannot have been motivated to retaliate by something he was unaware of”) (alteration in original) (quotation marks and citation omitted).",
      "associated_category": "Retaliation",
      "legal_background": "Ameen confirms that retaliation requires proof the decisionmaker knew of the protected activity; without knowledge, a retaliatory motive cannot be inferred. Employers can defeat retaliation claims by showing lack of awareness and continuity of performance-based expectations.",
      "relevance_score": "Medium"
    },
    {
      "law_cited": "Kinch v. Quest Diagnostics, Inc., 652 F. Supp. 2d 131, 133 (D. Mass. 2009)",
      "citation_context": "To establish a claim for failure to accommodate, Claimant must demonstrate that (1) she has a physical or mental impairment that substantially limits one or more major life activities, (2) with or without reasonable accommodation, she was a qualified individual able to perform the essential functions of the position involved, and (3) Respondents, despite knowing of her disability, did not reasonably accommodate it. Kinch v. Quest Diagnostics, Inc., 652 F. Supp. 2d 131, 133 (D. Mass. 2009).",
      "associated_category": "Disability (Failure to accommodate)",
      "legal_background": "Kinch articulates the ADA/Massachusetts failure-to-accommodate prima facie elements and underscores that the employee must be a qualified individual and the employer must know of the disability. It also supports that the accommodation duty is triggered by employee communication of the need.",
      "relevance_score": "High"
    },
    {
      "law_cited": "Russell v. Cooley Dickinson Hosp., Inc., 437 Mass. 443, 445 (2002)",
      "citation_context": "Complainant fails to establish a prima facie case of failure to accommodate because she applied and was approved for leaves of absence starting in May of 2024 and November 2024, which constitute reasonable accommodations under both the ADA and state law. Russell v. Cooley Dickinson Hosp., Inc., 437 Mass. 443, 445 (2002).",
      "associated_category": "Disability (Failure to accommodate)",
      "legal_background": "Russell recognizes that a leave of absence can be a reasonable accommodation where it enables the employee to perform essential functions upon return, absent undue hardship. Employers meet their burden when they grant medical leave consistent with the interactive process.",
      "relevance_score": "High"
    },
    {
      "law_cited": "Kinch, 652 F. Supp. 2d at 134",
      "citation_context": "Thus, her claim fails as a matter of law. Kinch, 652 F. Supp. 2d at 134 (“Typically, an employee must request an accommodation. That obligation ‘stems from the basic principle that an employer is not required to accommodate a need that it does not know exists.’”) (quoting Ocean Spray Cranberries, Inc. v. Mass. Comm'n Against Discrimination, 441 Mass. 632, 649 n. 21 (2004)).",
      "associated_category": "Disability (Failure to accommodate)",
      "legal_background": "This pinpoint in Kinch emphasizes that employers are not obligated to accommodate unknown needs; the employee must request or otherwise put the employer on notice. It reinforces the knowledge and request components of the accommodation burden.",
      "relevance_score": "Medium"
    },
    {
      "law_cited": "Ocean Spray Cranberries, Inc. v. Mass. Comm'n Against Discrimination, 441 Mass. 632, 649 n. 21 (2004)",
      "citation_context": "Thus, her claim fails as a matter of law. Kinch, 652 F. Supp. 2d at 134 (“Typically, an employee must request an accommodation. That obligation ‘stems from the basic principle that an employer is not required to accommodate a need that it does not know exists.’”) (quoting Ocean Spray Cranberries, Inc. v. Mass. Comm'n Against Discrimination, 441 Mass. 632, 649 n. 21 (2004)).",
      "associated_category": "Disability (Failure to accommodate)",
      "legal_background": "Ocean Spray supports the principle that an employer’s duty to accommodate arises only when the employer is on notice of the disability and need for accommodation. It is frequently cited to show that failure-to-accommodate claims falter if the employee never requested or identified a specific need.",
      "relevance_score": "Medium"
    },
    {
      "law_cited": "McLaughlin v. City of Lowell, 84 Mass. App. Ct. 45, 46 (2013)",
      "citation_context": "To the extent Complainant alleges that Respondents interfered with her rights under Chapter 151B, such a claim fails. “Absent actionable discriminatory conduct, there exists no basis on which to ground a claim of interference.” McLaughlin v. City of Lowell, 84 Mass. App. Ct. 45, 46 (2013).",
      "associated_category": "Interference (Mass. Gen. Laws c. 151B § 4(4A))",
      "legal_background": "McLaughlin holds that an interference claim under Chapter 151B requires underlying actionable discriminatory conduct; without discrimination, interference cannot stand. This places the burden on the employee to first prove a viable discrimination violation.",
      "relevance_score": "Medium"
    },
    {
      "law_cited": "Chapter 151B",
      "citation_context": "To the extent Complainant alleges that Respondents interfered with her rights under Chapter 151B, such a claim fails.",
      "associated_category": "Massachusetts anti-discrimination statute (Discrimination, Retaliation, Interference)",
      "legal_background": "Chapter 151B prohibits discrimination and retaliation in employment across protected classes and includes an interference provision. In employment cases, Massachusetts courts use the McDonnell Douglas burden-shifting framework: the employee must establish a prima facie case, the employer articulates a legitimate reason, and the employee must prove pretext. Also referenced elsewhere to argue that disputing performance concerns is not protected activity under Chapter 151B.",
      "relevance_score": "High"
    },
    {
      "law_cited": "Mass. Gen. Laws c. 151B",
      "citation_context": "Respondents have complied with all laws and regulations and otherwise satisfied their statutory obligations toward Complainant under Mass. Gen. Laws c. 151B and federal law.",
      "associated_category": "Massachusetts anti-discrimination statute (Compliance assertion)",
      "legal_background": "This is the statutory citation for Massachusetts’ anti-discrimination law governing discrimination, retaliation, and interference. Employers defend by showing compliance with non-discriminatory practices, legitimate performance-based actions, and engagement in accommodations when required.",
      "relevance_score": "Medium"
    },
    {
      "law_cited": "Title VII",
      "citation_context": "Further, to the extent that Complainant alleges that she was being retaliated against for purporting to dispute Ms. Benoit’s legitimate concerns about Complainant’s performance, such activities are not related to her stated disabilities or protected under Chapter 151B, Title VII, or the ADA, and thus cannot serve as a basis for her retaliation claim here.",
      "associated_category": "Race, Color, Religion, Sex, National Origin (and Retaliation)",
      "legal_background": "Title VII prohibits discrimination and retaliation based on race, color, religion, sex, and national origin. Under the burden-shifting framework, the employer must produce non-discriminatory reasons for adverse actions, and the employee must prove those reasons are pretext and that protected status or activity motivated the decision.",
      "relevance_score": "Medium"
    },
    {
      "law_cited": "ADA",
      "citation_context": "Complainant fails to establish a prima facie case of failure to accommodate because she applied and was approved for leaves of absence starting in May of 2024 and November 2024, which constitute reasonable accommodations under both the ADA and state law.",
      "associated_category": "Disability (Interactive process and reasonable accommodation; Retaliation)",
      "legal_background": "The Americans with Disabilities Act prohibits disability discrimination and requires employers to provide reasonable accommodations through an interactive process unless it causes undue hardship. In employment litigation, the employee must show a disability, qualification to perform essential functions, and failure by the employer to reasonably accommodate.",
      "relevance_score": "High"
    },
    {
      "law_cited": "804 CMR § 1.05(8)(d)",
      "citation_context": "I hereby certify and affirm, under pains and penalty of perjury, consistent with 804 CMR § 1.05(8)(d), that I have reviewed this Position Statement and that it contains accurate and truthful information to the best of my knowledge, information, and belief.",
      "associated_category": "MCAD procedural regulation (Position statement certification)",
      "legal_background": "This MCAD regulation requires respondents to certify position statements under penalties of perjury, ensuring accuracy and integrity in agency proceedings. It is procedural and does not bear on the substantive burden of proof for discrimination or retaliation.",
      "relevance_score": "Low"
    },
    {
      "law_cited": "Title Vi of the Civil Rights Act of 1964",
      "citation_context": "Boston Children's complies with Federal and State civil rights laws and regulations, and is committed to providing its programs and services without discrimination in accordance with: ◦ Title Vi of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, which prohibits discrimination based on race, color, or national origin (including language);",
      "associated_category": "Race, Color, National Origin (program access)",
      "legal_background": "Title VI prohibits discrimination on the basis of race, color, or national origin in programs and activities receiving federal financial assistance. It is cited in the hospital’s policy to demonstrate civil-rights compliance in services; it is not the employment statute governing the Charge.",
      "relevance_score": "Low"
    },
    {
      "law_cited": "Section 504 of Rehabilitation Act of 1973",
      "citation_context": "Boston Children's complies with Federal and State civil rights laws and regulations, and is committed to providing its programs and services without discrimination in accordance with: ◦ Section 504 of Rehabilitation Act of 1973, which prohibits discrimination based on disability;",
      "associated_category": "Disability (program access and reasonable accommodation)",
      "legal_background": "Section 504 bars disability discrimination by recipients of federal funds and requires reasonable modifications to ensure equal access. It is referenced in the hospital’s policy context rather than the employment discrimination framework at issue.",
      "relevance_score": "Low"
    },
    {
      "law_cited": "Title IX of the Education Amendments Act of 1972",
      "citation_context": "Boston Children's complies with Federal and State civil rights laws and regulations, and is committed to providing its programs and services without discrimination in accordance with: ◦ Title IX of the Education Amendments Act of 1972, which prohibits discrimination based on sex in education programs or activities;",
      "associated_category": "Sex (education programs)",
      "legal_background": "Title IX prohibits sex discrimination in federally funded education programs or activities. It is cited to show institutional compliance but does not govern the employment discrimination standards at issue in this Charge.",
      "relevance_score": "Low"
    },
    {
      "law_cited": "Age Discrimination Act of 1975",
      "citation_context": "Boston Children's complies with Federal and State civil rights laws and regulations, and is committed to providing its programs and services without discrimination in accordance with: ◦ Age Discrimination Act of 1975, which prohibits discrimination based on age;",
      "associated_category": "Age (program access)",
      "legal_background": "The Age Discrimination Act of 1975 prohibits age discrimination in programs and activities receiving federal financial assistance. Unlike the ADEA, it does not provide the employment ‘but-for’ causation standard; here it is mentioned in policy, not as the substantive employment law.",
      "relevance_score": "Low"
    },
    {
      "law_cited": "U.S. Department of Homeland Security regulation 6 C.F.R. Part 19",
      "citation_context": "Boston Children's complies with Federal and State civil rights laws and regulations, and is committed to providing its programs and services without discrimination in accordance with: ◦ U.S. Department of Homeland Security regulation 6 C.F.R. Part 19, which prohibits discrimination based on religion in social service programs.",
      "associated_category": "Religion (social service programs)",
      "legal_background": "6 C.F.R. Part 19 prohibits religious discrimination in certain social service programs funded by the U.S. Department of Homeland Security. It is a policy-level citation unrelated to the employment discrimination burdens litigated in the Charge.",
      "relevance_score": "Low"
    }
  ]
}
